text:
What stocks are on your radar this week?

What's in the news that's affecting the market?

Celebrate your successes, rue your losses, or just chat with your fellow Value redditors!

Take everything here with a grain of salt! We suggest checking other users' posting/commenting history before following advice or stock recommendations.  Watch out for shill accounts that pump the same stock all over Reddit, or have many posts/comments deleted in other investing subreddits. Stay safe!

*(New Weekly Megathreads are posted every Monday at 0600 GMT.)*

Is anybody a Vital Farms investor? I want to start a position but haven't completed the dive through the Financials. 

Highlights:
Rev growth ~35
Gross margin ~35
Current Assets ~2x+ current liabilities
Assets ~3x liabilities
Inventories and expenses aren't showing anything concerning imo. Seem in line with the previous year on a linear level.
Leases, among other expenses, don't show concern.

P/E is at 37ish, and CNBC shows fwd P/E at a similar number. I'm not sure that's accurate considering the growth and margins number. 

Market cap at 1.6b

Stock dilution looks like another 2 million shares out in warrants if I'm not mistaken. That should equate to around 5% dilution in the coming years. Somebody correct me if I'm missing something.

Bird flu hasn't had an impact on sales/margins according to their presentation.

Overall, it seems like a solid company with a lot of growth. I've been loving their eggs as a consumer and only recently discovered they were public. 

Point being, their eggs are fantastic (taste, richer, texture, etc) compared to your generic nutrientless white eggs you get. I can not go back to cheap white eggs. I know the difference now lol

They are much more expensive, so this really targets a bit higher than low income. 

I'm going to start scaling into this company and hope they have a major pullback in price for reasons that don't have anything to do with fundamentals (market wide pullback, etc).

Who else has looked into this? Valuation is rich, but it also seems high quality from a fundamental standpoint, so it'll naturally command a slightly higher premium, but I still would rather DCA.
ValueHunter is site that offers advice to investors.  Does anyone have experience with how useful the site is.?
Flexshopper
STLA
ASML. Dollar General. Evolution AB. Heineken.

I went big on VALE PAGS and PBR. Just in time to catch a small crash in the Brazilian Real. Lol fuck my life. 

But I still have high conviction in all three. Sitting tight.
CROX, ASO, RMAX
Stanley, Black & Decker (SWK) seems to be on the road to recovery.  EBIT expansion for the last 4 quarters.  3.86% div, PE 16.

I finally started a position in $AMAT after some pullback from weak guidance. Exposure to AI investment but diversified, healthy services revenue, great balance sheet, and reasonable valuations with reasonable growth.
Great value coming up at Pantheon - [https://oilman.beehiiv.com/p/oilman-jim-s-letter-december-10-2024](https://oilman.beehiiv.com/p/oilman-jim-s-letter-december-10-2024) \- check it out
Has anyone any thoughts on Chesnara? Dividend yields are huge almost 10% and the business seems boringly stable.
Is the market pricing in a WBD merger?
I did a quick write up for [United Health](https://fundamentalcharts.substack.com/p/united-health-group-fundamental-charts)

With a starting capital of 2 million and a 15% annual return, I could accumulate 14 million in 10 years and a staggering 35 million in 15 years. I'm truly amazed by these figures!

I wonder if those who take extreme risks, like gambling their entire net worth on a single stock, ever consider this approach. If it's possible to build wealth slowly and steadily, why would anyone gamble? The problem with betting without a solid strategy is that it's impossible to maintain consistent wins over 15 years or more. It's common sense that luck can't sustain such a long streak.
Anyone looking at Nucor

Valuation is pretty rich right now. I love the company, but not this much. 

I used their guidance of $1 billion in revenue by 2027 and came up with a price target ~$25 as a buy point.
Agree with ASML.

Replying to myself because I did some basic research: 
- company has plans to grow by a disciplined acquisitions process 
- dividend has increased in every one of the past 19 years 
- analyst targets see about 20% upside   

 I like this for growth potential plus a very reliable dividend.
I agree. That's why I have like 10% of what I want to own. There'll be an opportunity down the road for a more fair valuation. A market correction should do it.

Profit margins seem all over the place. Dividend payout was 722%. They booked a loss in 2022. I don't have time to do an in-depth. But what is your opinion on this. The net profit doesn't seem very consistent.
My problem is, if we get a broad based pullback, there's probably other options that become more attractive as well...

I mean, no shit. 

You won't know what's the best risk/reward going forward until you're there. You just put your favorite solid companies on your watch list and then pick up the best deals when the come available.

Very true. VITL actually came pretty close for me a few months ago. 

They also have the advantage of letting farms produce eggs and they basically package and distribute them.

Yeah. Practically a franchisee. I wasn't aware of them when they dropped into the 20s not long ago. Now I'm just waiting for the next opportunity.

I feel confident that we'll have a market correction by halfway through next year if we continue running up.

I don't disagree about the correction. Technically, a lot of names are starting to roll over. I look at VITL as follows. 

$1 billion in 2027 revenue (Management's goal, which they have a history of exceeding).

10% profit margin (about where it is today)

$100 million in profit. 

Throw a 20x on that,

It's a $2 billion company (currently $1.6 billion)

About a 25% gain over 3 years from current prices. 

At $1 billion market cap (about $25/share)

The math works out better. 100% gain in 3 years is excellent. 

I think there's also opportunity to increase their profit margins going forward. CALM actually has a higher profit margin, but VITL is spending on Capex right now too.

Yeah. The franchisee style business should give better yields in the long run. Does CALM have high-quality eggs like VITL, or is it only the cheap junk eggs?

Egg prices are like any other commodity, it'll have it's declines I'm sure.

I'm not sure about CALM honestly. VITL is the only name I've found out actual.brand loyalty. I forget the numbers, but a large percentage of their customers won't buy any other brand. I've never even heard of anything like that in the egg world. 

Also, my local grocery store frequently sells out of them. I have no doubt VITL is missing out on business and can capture it if they can produce more eggs.
I won't buy white eggs anymore. There's only a couple other brands I'll consider anymore.
